Dear Ms. O’Neill:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 2/3/2022.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and MISEP
requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved. For repeat violations,
please indicate why the previous CAP was not successful and what
changes will be made to ensure ongoing compliance.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
One of six licensing files held a renewal evaluation that was not submitted at least
15 days prior to expiration. The agency reported submitting the 3706 and application
on 6/7/21. However, the renewal evaluation was not approved until 6/14/21 and the
license expiration date was 6/20/21.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child…
One of six foster care files did not document the required information of subsections
(a-i) were provided to the foster parent prior to placement on 8/13/21.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/4/20 INTERIM, CAP approved 3/23/20
R 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a
youth before placement in independent living.
One of three independent living files did not have documentation the program
statement was provided to the youth prior to entering independent living.
R 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living with a
copy of the agency's policies and procedures required by this
rule.
One of three independent living files did not have documentation the policies and
procedures were provided to the youth prior to entering independent living.
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days:
(g) Current documentation of financial support sufficient to
meet the youth's housing, clothing, food, and miscellaneous
expenses.
4

R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
Two of three independent living files did not have IL contracts reviewed and provided
to the youth every 90 days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/4/20 INTERIM, CAP approved 3/23/20
1/12/21 RENEWAL, CAP approved 1/14/21
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-08E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, and upload to
MiSACWIS within the timeframe required for the specified
action/change...
 Caseworker/organization change- within three business
days.
 FC/IL case closure- within three business days.
 Placement change- prior to planned placement change or
with three business days of an emergency placement
change.
5

Three of nine open IL and foster care files, and three of three closed files, did not
meet the requirements for action summaries.
File one: A caseworker change occurred on 2/19/21 and the DHHS-69 was not
completed until 3/1/21. In addition, a DHHS-69 was not completed for the case
closing on 2/5/21.
File two: The youth moved on 9/3/21 and the DHHS-69 was not completed until
9/10/21.
File three: The youth moved on 8/13/21 and 8/27/21 and the DHHS-69 was not
completed until 12/1/21.
Three of three closed foster care cases did not have a completed DHHS-69.
FOM 722-16 Young Adult Voluntary Foster Care
The DHS-1295, Young Adult Monthly Visit Report, must be
completed with the youth during each home visit. A copy must
be uploaded into MiSACWIS a copy must be given to the youth.
Two of three IL/YAVFC cases did not have 1295 forms completed as required.
File one: 1295 forms were not completed for October and November 2021 visits.
File two: A 1295 form was not completed for the 11/18/21 visit.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
 Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
 Semi-Annual Transition meeting - Within 30 calendar
days after the youth’s 14th birthday and every six months
thereafter.
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, must be
completed at the conclusion of the FTM.
Two of nine foster care and IL files did not meet FTM requirements.
File one: An FTM on 5/28/21 did not have an 1105 completed. The 2/28/21 and
11/24/21 USPs did not have a corresponding FTM. The youth had a semi-annual
transition plan FTM on 3/31/20. The next one was completed late on 8/17/21.
File two: The 1/19/22 FTM did not have an 1105 completed.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/4/20 INTERIM, CAP approved 3/23/20
1/12/21 RENEWAL, CAP approved 1/14/21

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Licensing renewals- The 3706 with a recommendation for renewal must not
be submitted to DCWL prior to the renewal reevaluation (4004) being
completed, documenting the information that determined the
recommendation.
 The licensing reevaluation recommendation, 3706 and 3080 must have
matching recommendations regarding the number of children, age, gender,
and characteristics.
 CPR/first aid dates should be tracked aside from annual/renewal reports, in
order to identify those that expire in between reevaluations. This will allow the
agency an opportunity to gather updated documentation prior to expiration.
 YAVFC youth that live on their own are considered Independent Living youth
for licensing rules. YAVFC is a legal status, IL is the placement type.
Therefore, all IL requirements from the licensing rule book apply to YAVFC.
 Foster home visits- when completing the requirement for twice monthly face-
to-face contacts with youth in a new placement, the worker must be sure to
complete the contacts in a way that monthly home visit requirements are also
met.
 If a youth initiates the YAVFC process and a case is opened, but the youth
stops communicating with the agency, the agency must document attempts to
complete required items until case closure. For example, the agency must
document attempts to complete home visits, monthly budgets, 90-day IL
contract reviews, etc.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation during this review.
8

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse or neglect during this
licensing period.
There were two incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
One investigation was initiated after an allegation the foster father yelled at and
grabbed a foster child around the neck five times and pushed her head into her
sister’s head on purpose. Upon investigation, the foster family was found in violation
of rule 9404(3) behavior management, due to the foster father admitting he put his
hand on the back of the child’s neck to guide her to time-out. The corrective action
plan included the training “Novel approaches for handling your oppositional child”.
The CAP was completed on 5/14/21.
One investigation was initiated after an allegation the foster parent spanked a foster
child one time, about a year ago. Upon investigation, the foster parent was found in
violation of rule 9404(3) behavior management, due to the foster parent admitting
she spanked the foster child once in 2020. The CAP included training on trauma
informed parenting and behavioral health therapy. The CAP was completed on
6/30/21.
Both investigation reports were reviewed and found to meet licensing requirements.
The agency completed thorough investigations and developed appropriate CAPs
with timely follow-through. There have been no further concerns regarding these
foster families since the time of these investigations.
The agency has submitted three acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
A CAP, approved 1/14/21, was developed as a result of the 1/12/21 renewal review.
The review determined eleven violations of licensing rules and DHHS contract.
During this interim review fourteen violations were found, including seven repeat
violations. Partial compliance with the CAP was determined. During the exit
conference the agency reported the violations regarding independent living was due
to the agency misunderstanding the rules regarding IL and YAVFC. Technical
Assistance was provided and improvement in this area is anticipated during the next
reporting period.
A CAP, approved 4/15/21, was developed as the result of an investigation
(2021C0102013) in which it was determined the agency did not complete a special
evaluation in 2020 as required (Rule 400.12327), failed to assess an adult
household member in a foster home (Rule 400. 12206), and allowed an adult
household member on central registry to reside in a licensed foster home
(722.115q). The CAP included additional training, increased staff supervision, and
9

review of foster home members. The CAP was implemented by the agency and no
further concerns have been reported.
A CAP, approved 8/6/21, was developed as the result of an investigation
(2021C0116037) in which it was determined that relative home studies were not
completed timely (FOM 722-03B). The CAP included review of policy, updated
internal forms, and additional training. The CAP was implemented by the agency
and no further concerns have been reported.
Chief Administrator Assessment
During the on-site visit the Chief Administrator Assessment was discussed with the
Chief Administrator (CA). The CA reported the agency has had staffing challenges
over this past year, which has impacted timeliness of work. Staff have been working
a combination of remotely and in the office. Caseloads have been steady, and they
continue to have positive relationships with the referring counties. The CA indicated
the corrective action plan from last year has been implemented, although ongoing
COVID restrictions and staffing vacancies caused challenges in some areas.
However, the CA felt the agency has performed well overall.
Interviews
Two foster care staff were interviewed on-site. One staff reported being new to case
management, after prior experience working in a residential facility. The worker
reported enjoying the scope of the work and stated the agency and co-workers are
very helpful and supportive. The second staff reported being a case manager for
approximately one year. The worker stated she enjoys working with families,
although it can be challenging at times. The worker indicated the flexible schedule,
supportive team, and helpful supervision are appreciated. No concerns about the
agency were reported.
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Analyst identified two safety concerns as follows:
Safety Alert #1: A hot water heater was located in the closet of one of the bedrooms
in an unlicensed relative home. This room is occupied by the relative caregiver. A
mattress was found in the closet, leaning against the hot water heater.
Resolution: The family moved the mattress from the closet and placed a baby gate at
the closet door to prevent the children from accessing the water heater. Photos were
uploaded into the caregiver record in MiSACWIS.
Safety Alert #2: The foster parents were utilizing a loft space as a bedroom.
Although the family denied using the space for sleeping, a bed was observed in the
loft.
Resolution: The family enclosed the room by installing wood paneling over the open
wall area and making the room fully enclosed. Photos were uploaded into MiSACWIS
10

under the foster family’s record. The family then transferred their license to another
agency.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
